Sequential Estimation with Unestimated Parameters-the Fallacy
LAWRENCE SCHWARTZ Huges Aircraft Company. P.O. Box 92426, Los Angeles. Calif. 90009
Communicated by J. M. Richardson
ABSTRACT
The derivation of formulas for sequential estimation in the presence of unestimated uncertain parameters is the subject of earlier papers. It is shown herein that the estimation procedure involves the involuntary estimation of the uncertain parameters.
INTRODUCTION
In [1,2] the equations for the optimal linear sequential estimator are found for a model with uncertain parameters that are not to be estimated, though the uncertainty is to be accounted for in the estimation. The resulting estimator formula is compared with the sequential estimation formula when the uncertain parameters are adjoined to the state vector and estimated. It is shown that the two estimators require vectors and matrices of equal number and dimensions. In other words, in the unestimated parameters case there are analogs of the vector of the parameters, the covariance of the parameters, and the covariance of the parameters with the state. It is shown in the sequel that the estimates are identical in both cases and that the analog of the parameter vector is a linear transformation of the parameter vector obtained from the estimated parameter case.
